text: SMOKING CESSATION BY MAIL: A COMPARISON OF STANDARD AND PERSONALIZED CORRESPONDENCE COURSE FORMATS
Self-Instructional behavior-change programs for reducing risks to health are potentially widely available, acceptable and cost-effective.
This paper reports outcomes of a smoking cessation program administered by mail.
Two hundred and eight smokers were allocated systematically to a quit kit control condition (n = 40).
to a standard correspondence course (n = 86) and to a personalized correspondence course prepared with the aid of a microcomputer (n = 82).

There were significantly higher rates of abstinence after the course for correspondence course participants compared to controls, but these differences did not persist at three-month and nine-month follow-ups.
There were no differences between the personalized and standard courses on abstinence rates, number of cigarettes smoked per day, or return of feedback forms on each lesson.
There were associations between self-efficacy strength and reduced rates of smoking, and active participation in the course was associated with lower smoking rates.
Two hundred and eight (93 female, 115 male) smokers entered the program.
Their mean age was 42 years (SD = 11 years).
Using the Australian Bureau of Statistics classification of occupations), 55% were white collar workers, 33% home duties, and 12% blue collar.

They had previously made an average of 3.6 serious attempts to stop smoking, smoked an average of 27.6 cigarettes per day (range = 10 to 60), and had smoked for an average of 24 years (range = 2 to 41).
Participants were recruited by public advertisement.

A media release was sent to local radio, television, and newspapers; interviews and articles were broadcast and published over a two-week period; and advertisements for the course were placed in Adelaide's morning daily newspaper on two successive days.
Three hundred and twelve smokers responded.
They were sent a course registration form and covering letter, which gave a brief description of the course and requested that they complete the registration form and return it with a $20 course fee.
It was explained that $10 of that fee would be refunded contingent upon the return of questionnaires during the program.
Of those who responded initially, 67% entered the program.

Participants were allocated randomly to a quit kit control conditions or to one of two intervention conditions, with the constraint that there be equal numbers above and below the median number of cigarettes per day (median = 25) in each condition, and that there be approximately twice as many participants in each of the intervention conditions as in the control condition.

This imbalance was created because ethically it was considered desirable to offer treatment to as many participants as possible; and because the comparison between standard and personalized interventions was central to this investigation, and maximization of power for this comparison was seen as important.
There were 40 participants in the control condition, 86 in the standard correspondence course and 82 in the personalized correspondence course.
Those in the control condition had their course fee returned with a letter of apology, explaining that because of the large number of registrations, the course could not be offered to them.
A "quit kit" (Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, undated) was enclosed, and they were advised to try it.

The kit included a five-day cessation plan, gave practical tips for cessation and brief instruction in progressive muscle relaxation, outlined the effects of smoking on health, and included a cigarette pack wrapping sheet for self-monitoring and a card on which reasons for cessation and benefits could be written.
The materials in the quit kit resembled some of those in the correspondence course, but in an abbreviated form.
This consisted of four lessons mailed at weekly intervals.
Lessons dealt with preparing for cessation, initial cessation, coping with urges to smoke, and remaining a nonsmoker (maintenance).
These stages were adapted from the sequence suggested by.

Course content included advice on progressive muscle relaxation, a deep breathing technique to assist with relaxation and distraction, outlines of cognitive and behavioral coping skills, self-instruction, goal setting and covert verbalization techniques, and advice on social support and contingency contracts.
The cessation technique recommended was to halve daily smoking rate for three days prior to a time chosen in advance as the quit date.

It was emphasized that the course provided a sequence to be followed that could lead to cessation, and could help to prevent resumption of smoking, but it was also presented as a set of lessons in cessation skills which could be used at anytime in the future.
This used the same content, sequence of lessons and mailing schedule as the standard course.
Rather than being photocopied, the lessons for the personalized course were generated for each individual using a microcomputer.
Personalized course segments were sets of extra paragraphs inserted into the text of the standard course.

The contents of these were determined by information from the course registration form relating to: motivation to attempt cessation, number of cigarettes smoked per day, subjective belief in addiction, concerns about weight gain, and self-efficacy.
For example, one personalized course segment stated, "From what you have told us, you are not very confident about being able to resist the offer of a cigarette in social situations.
You should practice ways to say 'no' nicely and plan in advance what to say; you could be firm, but also make a joke of it to help the other person not to feel offended by your refusal."

Self-efficacy items were selected from those with the highest cluster loadings reported by Condiotte and Lichtenstein (198 1) and from items found to be most strongly predictive of cessation by Owen,: These dealt with coping with negative affect and with urges to smoke in response to situational and emotional stimuli, and confidence about remaining abstinent.
Weight control, fitness, and reduced smoking options were offered in the personalized course. and sent as separate mailings on request.
Participants were sent the first lesson of the course within two weeks of having returned the registration form.
The three subsequent lessons were sent at one-week intervals.
Feedback forms requesting information on use of course components and on current smoking status were enclosed with a prepaid return envelope in each of the four lessons.

entities.text: requesting information on use of course components

text: Up to $10 of the course fee was refundable contingent upon the return of feedback forms: $2.50 perform returned.
This incentive was intended to be a means of increasing active involvement, and return of feedback forms was to be used as a possible index of involvement.

Five days after the last lesson was mailed, course participants and control subjects were interviewed by telephone to determine whether or not they were smoking, how many cigarettes per day they had smoked recently, and if they had stopped during the course.
Saliva samples for thiocyanate assay had been obtained from 31 randomly selected participants in the two correspondence courses prior to the program.
Repeat samples were obtained from 25 of them, 7 to 10 days after the final lesson was mailed.
Participants were contacted by telephone three months and nine months after the end of the course, and asked for information on their current smoking habits.
Repeat telephone calls were made until participants could be contacted, or until it was determined that they were unavailable.
At the nine month follow-up, urine was collected from 13 of those reporting abstinence, and cotinine assays (Jacob, were conducted.
Participants from whom urine and saliva samples were collected were not warned prior to the course that this would be done.

They were contacted by telephone or letter and asked if a research assistant could visit their house the following day to obtain the samples, as part of research the University was doing on smoking and health.
There was a refusal rate of approximately 15% for each of these collections.

There were no significant initial differences between participants in the three conditions on age, smoking rate, number of previous attempts at cessation, motivation, self-efficacy, or on the other variables assessed.
Data were available from 208 participants (100%) at the beginning of the study, 194 (93%) immediately afterwards, 164 (79%) at three-month follow-up, and 184 (88%) at nine-month follow-up.
Percentages available for follow-up were similar for the three experimental conditions.
Abstinence and reductions in smoking rate shows rates of abstinence at each follow-up, expressed as a percentage of the original number of participants in each condition.
At the end of the course there were significantly more abstainers in the two intervention conditions than in the control condition (chi-square = 6.27, df = 1, p < 0.05).
The difference was significant at three months (chi-square = 4.72, df = 1, p = O.S), but not at nine months (chi-square = 3.55, df = 1, p = 0.17).
There were no differences between the standard and personalized course outcomes on any of these occasions.
The smoking rate data produced similar results to the abstinence data.
Before the course, mean smoking rates (cigarettes per day) were: standard course, 28.4, personalized course, 27.5, controls, 26.2 (F < 1).

Participants in the standard and personalized correspondence courses were smoking significantly fewer cigarettes per day (means = 15.1 and 15.4 respectively) than were those in the control condition (mean = 21.6) immediately after the intervention (F[2,188] = 3.21, p = 0.04).
There were no significant differences between conditions at three months (F = 1.73, p = 0.18) nor at nine months (F = 0.68, p = 0.5).
There were no differences in smoking rates between the standard and personalized courses on any of these occasions.
Return of feedback forms on each lesson was monitored as an index of the extent to which participants involved themselves actively in the use of each lesson.

In the standard course, percentages of participants returning each of the four feedback forms were 72, 55,49 and 37 respectively, while in the personalized course the return rates were 73, 5 1, 43 and 42: These rates of return did not differ significantly between the two versions of the course.

For reported number of cigarettes per day after the course, there were significant differences between those who returned the final feedback form (mean = 10.9) and those who did not (mean = 18.5) (F[1,167] = 11.7, p < ,001).
Of the 31 participants on whom saliva thiocyanate assays were conducted prior to the course, 25 were available for repeat assays after the course.
Of these participants, five reported complete abstinence.
Four had large reductions in thiocyanate levels, but one who reported abstinence had an increased level of saliva thiocyanate relative to his preintervention level.

If cessation rates at the end of the course are adjusted downwards by one-fifth (from 37 to 30 abstinent), there is still a significant difference between the abstinence rates for the two interventions combined and the control (chi-square = 6.07, df = 1, p < .05).
Urine samples were obtained from 13 of the participants reporting abstinence at the nine-month follow-up.
Cotinine assays using a gas chromatographic method were conducted (Jacob..
For active smokers, the expected range for this measure is .044 mg/l to 1 .O mg/l.
Two of the 13 had cotinine levels indicative of recent smoking (0.49 mg/l and 0.13 mg/l).
From these findings, it would appear that reports of abstinence were generally accurate, but that abstinence rates derived from self-report data might be inflated by approximately 15%.
The 16 - item self-efficacy scale was completed by 186 participants before the course and by the 58 who returned the feedback questionnaire on the fourth lesson.
Initial self-efficacy ratings for all 186 participants did not differ among the three experimental conditions.
(The means were 57, 54, & 55 on a loo-point scale for the standard course, personalized course and controls, respectively.)
The mean initial self-efficacy rating for those who were abstinent at the end of the course was 60; for those who were still smoking at the end of the course it was 55.
This difference was not statistically significant.
The initial mean efficacy score for those 58 participants on whom final efficacy ratings were available was 56: for those who did not provide a final efficacy rating it was 55.
Mean self-efficacy ratings increased from 56 to 69 (F[ 1.541 = 10.52, p < .O 1) by the end of the course.
Self-efficacy after the course was significantly higher for those who were abstinent (mean = 88) than for those who were still smoking (mean = 58); F(1.56) = 36.9, p < .OO 1.
At the end of the course, mean self-efficacy scores were 57 for the personalized course, and 74 for the standard course (F[ 1,561 = 4.03, p < .05).
These data are based on the 58 persons for whom initial and final self-efficacy ratings were available.
There were small but significant negative correlations for cigarettes smoked per day immediately following the program, both with initial self-efficacy ratings (1.
p < .Ol), and with the final self-efficacy rating (I = -.35, II = 58. p < .Ol).
Abstinence rates following smoking cessation programs can be expressed as a percentage of those initially abstinent, with rates of 25% at 6 to 12 months commonly reported.

Using the number of smokers reporting abstinence for at least two days after the designated quit date as the denominator, the percentage abstinence rates subsequent to the standard and personalized course can be compared.

Of those who were successful in abstaining for at least two days, those in the personalized course were significantly more likely to be abstinent at the end of the course (two weeks after their quit date).
but there were no significant differences between groups at three-or nine-month follow-up.

Participation in either version of the correspondence course was associated with significant short-term decreases in smoking rate and higher levels of abstinence compared to a quit kit control condition.
Differences between the standard and personalized courses on smoking cessation or reduction were small.
Return of feedback forms on the lessons was associated with significantly lower rates of smoking at the end of the course.
suggesting that those who were more actively involved in the program had more success.
An attempt was made to verify self-report data by the use of biochemical measures; although only a small sample was tested, the results in general supported the self-report information.

Short-term cessation rates were comparable to or better than those reported by previous studies of self-instructional materials with media or face-to-face support (e.g.,: they were significantly higher than the very low rate of cessation in the control group.
The personalized version of the course.
tailored to smoker characteristics, did not result in enhanced effectiveness, contrary to the suggestions of and.

Although there were no significant differences in abstinence rates between the standard and personalized courses, self-efficacy ratings fi~l!~~in.g the >ersonalized course were significantly lower than ratings f,:llcwinp t:;?

it 15 possible that participants' confidence in remaining ~~~sGww wnc undermined 53 the receipt cf this personalized advice; it may have conveyed an impression that giving up smoking is a very difficult procedure, requiring sophisticated testing and expert interpretation of personal characteristics, and thus was seen as less a matter of personal initiative.
Further research on the impact of personalizing this type of program should be conducted, however, before such efforts are abandoned.
personalized e!ements may not have been sufficiently distinctive, embedded as they were in the teut of the course.
Future invectigations could use a course format where ali perqlmalired information was presented in a letter that accompanied standard lessons.
This may enhance the distinctiveness of personalized material, and would be less difficult to produce thun ? complete 1~s~ m the personalized format.

There is considerable potential for developing personalized selfinstructional materials and course formats such as this into interactive computer software, extending the approach suggested by. suggestion that self-instructional programs may produce "sleeper effects" (an increase in abstinence rate overtime subsequent to the program) was not supported by the present findings, which showed the percentage of participants abstinent to decrease subsequent to the interventions.

Condiotte and Lichtenstcin's (198 1) and findings that self-efficacy was predictive of chary in smoking behavior can be tentatively supported by the findings that the successful participants had higher self-efficacy than those who were not successful.
For a program conducted entirely through the mail.
this correspondence course had a significant, although short-term, impact on reported smoking behavior.

The findings lend some support to the case for the potential of correspondence courses as widely available, structured, cost-effective services for smokers who desire assistance with attempts at cessation.
This particular program was superior to a control condition in the short term.
Although the longer-term advantage did not reach statistical significance.
it should be pointed out that this was a pilot program which can be further refined on the basis of participant response.
Research on mediated behavior-change programs like these has inherent difficulties, such as the need to compromise on matters of experimental design, and loss of participants to follow-up.
The acceptability of such programs to the general public is also an issue which requires investigation.
It would be useful to determine the percentage of smokers who might be willing to try such a mediated approach.
argues that about two-thirds of smokers who wish to stop would prefer self-help approaches to face-to-face methods.

If effective programs are to be made widely available to deal with large-scale public health problems like cigarette smoking, such research, and the stronger integration of theoretical perspectives into program development and evaluation, is crucial.
Strategies for behavior change derived from controlled experimental investigations can be used in the development of widely available, mediated programs.
The challenge is to apply our knowledge as rigorously as possible to programs which have the potential to reach the largest number of people.
